greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest m for which m^n = Sum_{x in S} x^n has no solution S subset of {1, ..., m-1}.
comment: Row n of table A332065 lists all s for which there is some S subset of {1,...,m-1} with s^n = Sum_{x in S} x^n. This is the case for all sufficiently large s (cf. reference there). Here we give the largest integer not in this list.

Sequence A030052 lists the smallest m for which there is a solution, so a(n) >= A030052(n) - 1. We have a(9) = 51 = A030052(9) + 4, a(10) = 62 = A030052(10) - 1, a(11) = 72 = A030052(11) + 4. - _M. F. Hasler_, May 14 2020, edited Jul 19 2020
example: For n=1, we have m^n = (m-1)^n + 1^n, so S = {1, m-1} is a solution for all m > 2, but 2^n > 1^n and therefore no solution with m = 2 = a(1).
For n=2, we have a solution to m^n = Sum_{x in S} x^n for S subset of {1,...,m-1} for all m > 8 (cf. FORMULA in A332065), but no solution with m = 8 = a(2).
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 19 2020
ext: a(8) - a(12) from _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 23 2020
